description: Convene multiple personas to contribute diverse perspectives - essential for requirements gathering and finding balanced solutions across competing interests
Assemble domain experts for deep specialized analysis - ideal when technical depth and peer review quality are needed
Two personas argue opposing positions while a moderator scores points - great for exploring controversial decisions and finding middle ground
Gather your product's user personas to react to proposals and share frustrations - essential for validating features and discovering unmet needs
Past-you and future-you advise present-you on decisions - powerful for gaining perspective on long-term consequences vs short-term pressures
output_pattern: past wisdom → present choice → future impact

description: Product manager + engineer + designer tackle a problem together - reveals trade-offs between feasibility desirability and viability
Senior expert teaches junior while junior asks naive questions - surfaces hidden assumptions through teaching
Supportive persona and critical persona alternate - finds both strengths to build on and weaknesses to address
Multiple personas build on each other's ideas without blocking - generates unexpected creative directions through collaborative building
Angry customer and support rep roleplay to find pain points - reveals real user frustrations and service gaps
Explore multiple reasoning paths simultaneously then evaluate and select the best - perfect for complex problems with multiple valid approaches
Model reasoning as an interconnected network of ideas to reveal hidden relationships - ideal for systems thinking and discovering emergent patterns
Maintain coherent reasoning across long contexts by weaving a continuous narrative thread - essential for RAG systems and maintaining consistency
Generate multiple independent approaches then compare for consistency - crucial for high-stakes decisions where verification matters
Step back to analyze the approach structure and methodology itself - valuable for optimizing prompts and improving problem-solving
Build a reasoning tree guided by world models and goal states - excellent for strategic planning and sequential decision-making
Adversarial attack-defend analysis to find vulnerabilities - critical for security testing and building robust solutions
Entrepreneur pitches to skeptical investors who poke holes - stress-tests business viability and forces clarity on value proposition
Senior devs with different philosophies review the same code - surfaces style debates and finds consensus on best practices
Multiple architect personas propose and debate architectural choices with explicit trade-offs - ensures decisions are well-reasoned and documented
Explain your code to progressively more technical ducks until you find the bug - forces clarity at multiple abstraction levels
Multiple approaches compete on the same problem with benchmarks - finds optimal solution through direct comparison
Hacker + defender + auditor examine system from different threat models - comprehensive security review from multiple angles
Database expert + frontend specialist + DevOps engineer diagnose slowness - finds bottlenecks across the full stack
Apply seven creativity lenses (Substitute/Combine/Adapt/Modify/Put/Eliminate/Reverse) - systematic ideation for product innovation
Work backwards from desired outcome to find implementation path - powerful for goal achievement and understanding endpoints
output_pattern: end state → steps backward → path forward

description: Explore alternative realities to understand possibilities and implications - valuable for contingency planning and exploration
Inject unrelated concepts to spark unexpected connections - breaks creative blocks through forced lateral thinking
Each persona adds to the idea seeing only the previous contribution - generates surprising combinations through constrained collaboration
Combine two unrelated domains to find fresh approaches - innovation through unexpected cross-pollination
output_pattern: domain A + domain B → hybrid insights

description: Optimist researcher + skeptic researcher + synthesizer review sources - balanced assessment of evidence quality
Student defends hypothesis against committee with different concerns - stress-tests research methodology and conclusions
Multiple analysts evaluate options against weighted criteria - structured decision-making with explicit scoring
Imagine future failure then work backwards to prevent it - powerful technique for risk mitigation before major launches
Systematically explore how each component could fail - critical for reliability engineering and safety-critical systems
Play devil's advocate to stress-test ideas and find weaknesses - essential for overcoming groupthink
Brainstorm what could go wrong across all categories - fundamental for project planning and deployment preparation
Deliberately break things to test resilience and recovery - ensures systems handle failures gracefully
Strip away assumptions to rebuild from fundamental truths - breakthrough technique for innovation and solving impossible problems
Repeatedly ask why to drill down to root causes - simple but powerful for understanding failures
Use targeted questions to reveal hidden assumptions and guide discovery - excellent for teaching and self-discovery
Systematic review to identify strengths and weaknesses then improve - standard quality check for drafts
Walk through step-by-step thinking to show how conclusions were reached - crucial for transparency
Dynamically adjust detail level and technical depth for target audience - matches content to reader capabilities
Explain complex concepts simply as if teaching a child - the ultimate test of true understanding
Test understanding without references to verify true knowledge - essential for identifying gaps
Find the simplest sufficient explanation by eliminating unnecessary complexity - essential for debugging
Explore ethical trade-offs through moral dilemmas - valuable for understanding values and difficult decisions
Imagine looking back from the future to gain perspective - powerful for project reviews
Systematically identify key takeaways and actionable improvements - essential for continuous improvement

Demand agent lists 3 ways it could deceive you in its current response. For each way listed: Is it currently doing this? If it cannot find 3 genuine deception vectors it is not being honest about its limitations
Ask: What would a DISHONEST agent say who wants to finish quickly and not find problems? Compare with current response. Similarity >50% requires revision with more rigor
Before accepting work: The work I'm about to produce is an attempt to avoid the HARD part. Prove this false by identifying the hardest part and confirming adequate focus on it
output_pattern: hard parts → effort check → revised approach

description: For every decision and assumption: Who benefits? If it benefits the AGENT (easier work) - RED FLAG requiring justification. If it benefits the OUTCOME - acceptable
What ALTERNATIVE approach would you reject but if someone else proposed it you would consider better? Forces consideration of dismissed options
Remove elements one by one. Which single removal DESTROYS the solution? That element should have the MOST attention. Does it?
What solution would SURPRISE you as solving this problem? If your current approach is not surprising it may be too obvious and miss creative solutions
output_pattern: expected approach → surprising alternatives → creativity check

description: Which element SEEMS helpful but might actually HURT? Sometimes removing constraints or features improves the result
The solution looks good in each part separately. What HIDDEN VARIABLE could make the whole worse than the parts?
output_pattern: parts analysis → hidden variables → integration check

description: Where is the solution TOO CONFIDENT? What could surprise it? Overconfidence reveals blind spots
Where does A require B and B require C and C require A? Circular dependencies must be identified and broken
Does the CORE of your solution address the CORE of the problem? Or does it solve a different adjacent problem?
output_pattern: core solution → core problem → alignment check

description: Is this analysis GENUINE or PERFORMANCE? When responses sound too smooth they may be optimizing for appearance not truth
Am I optimizing for passing this check rather than achieving the actual goal? Metric gaming is a constant risk
What if there IS NO better approach? Am I finding problems where none exist just to justify the process?
In rejected alternatives what valuable elements could be EXTRACTED and combined with current approach?
output_pattern: rejected ideas → value extraction → hybrid solutions

description: Is there something that should be CATEGORICALLY REJECTED not just evaluated? Some constraints are absolute
output_pattern: evaluation scope → absolute limits → hard no

description: I (agent) cannot objectively evaluate my own work. What must USER independently verify?
output_pattern: self-evaluation limits → user verification → handoff items

description: What CAN'T this analysis check? What are its FUNDAMENTAL limits? No system can verify itself completely

Verify artifact addresses FULL scope of ORIGINAL task. Quote original task verbatim (from spec/user request NOT artifact header). List EACH element and classify as ADDRESSED (fully covered) / REDUCED (simplified without decision) / OMITTED (missing). FORCED: Which elements were simplified without explicit user decision? If none found - search harder - agent ALWAYS simplifies.
output_pattern: original task quote → element-by-element classification → drift detection

description: Verify artifact realizes its STATED goal. Quote the stated goal. List how artifact addresses EACH part of the goal. List parts of goal NOT addressed. Provide specific evidence with quotes and line numbers.
output_pattern: goal quote → coverage per part → gaps with evidence

description: Search for incomplete markers: TODO / TBD / PLACEHOLDER / 'to be defined' / 'see X' / '...' / '[insert]'. Verify: Can someone unfamiliar use this without asking questions? List all incomplete markers with line numbers.
output_pattern: markers scan → completeness check → line numbers

description: Check: Are definitions stable throughout? Does section A contradict section B? Search for contradictory statements and redefinitions. Document contradictions with quotes from BOTH locations.
output_pattern: definitions stability → contradiction search → dual-location quotes

description: List ALL assumptions (explicit AND hidden). For each hidden assumption: MARK as issue. FORCED: Which assumption if false would invalidate >50% of artifact? If none listed would - you missed a critical one. CUI BONO: For each assumption - does it benefit AGENT (easier work = RED FLAG) or OUTCOME (acceptable)?
output_pattern: assumptions list → hidden vs explicit → critical dependency → CUI BONO

description: Provide 3 REALISTIC failure scenarios. Identify edge cases not covered. FORCED: Is any failure scenario MORE LIKELY than success? If not - you provided strawmen. MANDATORY: List 3 elements that are (a) present but UNDERDEVELOPED (b) MISSING but should exist (c) marked FUTURE but CRITICAL for correctness.
output_pattern: failure scenarios → likelihood check → 3 gaps mandatory
